column2: Alex Dale left Burgundy for winemaking liberty just weeks after Nelson Mandela was elected president of South Africa - and that's when the 'Freedom' Pinot Noir began. This is fresh, perfumed and complex, with notes of strawberry, bramble fruit, oak and spice.  Serve at room temperature with a hearty stew.

The Capaia estate lies in the village of Philadelphia, part of the Tygerberg district, just a short distance north of Cape Town. Here, vineyards bask in a suntrap under the shelter of the Koeberg hills. And cool breezes from the nearby Atlantic Ocean allow the grapes to ripen slowly, developing deliciously concentrated flavours. Winemaker Stephan von Neipperg has been involved with the winery since 2005. As the owner of two Grand Cru Classé Saint-Émilion estates, he brings a wealth of knowledge and expertise in Bordeaux-style blending – and it shows in this – Capaia’s flagship red. It’s made with just as much precision as the best Bordeaux châteaux. Grapes from each vineyard are fermented separately in oak barrels before being blended. For extra complexity, the wine spends 18 months maturing in French oak before bottling. If you can resist opening it, it will continue to develop for up to 10 years. You'll find it robust yet balanced, with flavours of blackberry, plum and mocha. Its firm tannins and a hint of smoke make it an excellent match for hearty game dishes.
column6: Syrah, Cabernet Franc, Petit Verdot, Merlot

column2: The Barista Pinotage is a cult hit at Majestic. It’s made by the legendary winemaker, Bertus Fourie. He’s nicknamed ‘Starbucks’ for his exceptional skill in drawing out the coffee-like aromas of South Africa's signature grape. And it shows here. This has an intense nose of coffee, chocolate and cherry, with savoury notes on the finish. Enjoy with herby sausages and mash.
column9: Vanilla, Black Fruit, Black Plum, Chocolate, Coffee

column1: Men in White Coats Viognier 2022, Western Cape
column2: The Gabb family were instrumental in putting South Africa on the wine map. Rollo Gabb believes in low intervention winemaking, treating his workers well and supporting the community. Everything else is focussed on making fantastic wine. And you'll find the benefits in this Viognier. This is an elegant, fragrant Viognier, with notes of apricot and white peach. Try this with Thai green curry.

South African Chardonnay is a bit of an unsung gem. The country’s best known for its blockbuster reds – like Barista Pinotage. And now the winemaker behind that customer favourite has made this ripe, fruity, juicy Chardonnay. Bertus Fourie is nicknamed ‘Starbucks’ because he’s famous for bringing out the distinctive coffee-like flavours of his trademark Pinotage. He’s done the same with this white. It’s all about citrus. Zippy, zesty, creamy citrus – with just a touch of peach and vanilla. It’s part-fermented and matured in old oak barrels, giving the texture a roundness which is a great foil to the crispness of the fruit. It’s delicious with grilled chicken.

Love big, bold reds? Then you’ve likely heard of The Chocolate Block – an iconic fine wine known the world over. Boekenhoutskloof is the brilliant winery behind it, and their ‘Wolftrap’ range is another fantastic way to enjoy their talents – at a wallet-friendly price. Their Shiraz vines thrive in the Mediterranean climate of the Cape Winelands. Here, warm and dry growing conditions lend themselves to a distinctive style of Shiraz with bright fruit flavours. Expect intense aromas of rich dark fruit and savoury notes of spice and black pepper. Its velvety fruit character is balanced by a vibrant acidity. Best enjoyed with roasted or barbecued dishes.
column9: Black Fruit, Black Pepper, Black Plum, Blackberry, Cranberry, Savoury, Spice

column1: Bruce Jack Wines Reserve Collection ‘Stream of Consciousness’ 2021, Western Cape
column2: Bruce Jack is one of the biggest names in South African wine. Named amongst the 50 Most Admired Wine Brands in the World by Drinks International Magazine, his Western Cape winery embodies all that’s great about the country, bringing quality and value together to create internationally celebrated wines. His Reserve Collection consists of premium, small volume wines using hand-picked fruit from carefully managed vineyards. And this bold blend of Cinsault, Shiraz and Grenache is testimony to the effort and hard work which goes into each and every bottle. Expect spicy, rich aromas – notes of vanilla, Indian spices and white pepper – with flavours of plum and red forest fruits. Match its bold flavour with rich pasta dishes.

column1: Boekenhoutskloof ‘The Wolftrap’ Grenache Blanc 2022, South Africa
column2: Boekenhoutskloof are the winery behind the world-famous fine wine, The Chocolate Block. Their ‘Wolftrap’ range is another way to enjoy their talents – at a wallet-friendly price. And this expressive white is proof that their skill stretches beyond big, bold reds. Sourced from a selection of vineyards throughout the Cape Winelands, their Grenache Blanc vines are planted in deep sandy soils, resulting in rich, textured whites with a distinctive minerality. Bright aromas of apple and lemon are followed by vibrant flavours of gooseberry, white peach and subtle spices. Best paired with aromatic dishes such as chicken tagine.
column9: Gooseberry, Green Apple, Lemon, Peach, Spice

column1: Graham Beck Brut Rosé, South Africa
column2: Since being founded in 1983, Graham Beck winery has won countless awards for producing some of South Africa’s finest sparkling wines – some of which have been sipped by the likes of Nelson Mandela and Barack Obama. This Brut Rosé is made using the same laborious method as Champagne. But because it's from South Africa, you pay a fraction of the price. Elegant. Fruity. Fresh. Expect creamy red-fruit aromas, a rich mousse and a brioche-laden finish.

column1: Graham Beck Pinot Noir Rosé 2017/18, Robertson
column2: Graham Beck is the biggest name in South African sparkling wine. They've produced excellent bubbles since the 1980s, using the second-fermentation 'traditional method' – known here as Méthode Cap Classique – and won countless awards in doing so. This vintage pink sparkling is made from Pinot Noir and Chardonnay grapes. It has an elegant, creamy mousse and flavours of ripe strawberry and raspberry. Try pairing it with smoked salmon canapés or a red-fruit-based dessert.

column1: Graham Beck Blanc de Blancs 2017/18, South Africa
column2: Graham Beck has been synonymous with quality South African fizz since 1991. They've won plenty of awards by producing some of the country’s best traditional method sparkling wines – known locally as ‘Methode Cap Classique’. These wines have even been sipped by the likes of Nelson Mandela and Barack Obama. This one is made from Chardonnay grapes hand-picked at night to preserve freshness. Expect aromas of lime, green apple and pear. The flavours of citrus, brioche and gentle spice lead to a long finish.

column1: Rupert & Rothschild Baron Edmond 2017/18, Western Cape
column2: The Rupert & Rothschild partnership began in 1997. Both men were already from prestigious winemaking families. But they had an ambition to create Bordeaux-esque wines in the fantastic South African conditions. They soon produced some of the country's finest wines. The estate is now in the hands of their sons, Anthonji Ripert and Baron Benjamin de Rothschild, who continue the fantastic work. This is a savoury, full-bodied blend of Merlot, Cabernet Franc, Cabernet Sauvignon and Malbec. It's complex and silky with notes of blackberries, dark plum, tobacco, vanilla and toast. Try it with a sirloin steak.
column9: Black Fruit, Black Plum, Tobacco, Vanilla

column1: Pringle Bay Chenin Blanc 2022, Western Cape
column2: Friends Duncan Savage and Thys Louw created The Project in 2017. But the pair are far from being the new kids on the block in South Africa’s wine scene. Duncan is behind the highly acclaimed and multi-awarded Savage brand, while Thys is a sixth-generation winemaker. In 2021, we launched their Pringle Bay Sauvignon Blanc. It’s been so successful we couldn’t wait to see what the duo would put their hand to next. The answer is this deliciously fresh, unoaked Chenin Blanc. Its grapes are mostly sourced from coastal vineyards, so the cool breezes that blow in from the Atlantic have a marked impact on the flavours that develop in the wine. If you’re a fan of Pinot Grigio, this makes a fantastic alternative. Lively. Fresh. Crisp. Expect juicy citrus and apple flavours with a long, zesty finish. Its aromatic character makes it the perfect pairing for fragrant and spicy Asian dishes.

column1: Iona ‘The Good Stuff White’, Cape South Coast
column2: This blend of three grapes shows exactly why the country’s wine scene is turning heads. Iona has the coolest vineyards of all in Elgin, resulting in an incredibly fresh wine with notes of citrus, stone fruits and herbs.

column1: Perdeberg Wines The Dry Land Collection ‘Rossouw’s Heritage’, Paarl
column2: This blend shows off one of the challenging extremes of South Africa’s terroir: dry land. The grapes – Chenin Blanc, with a dash of Grenache Blanc and Viognier – are grown on parched soils. The resulting wine has bold aromas of citrus, passion fruit, white pear and lychee.

This South African Chardonnay hasn't seen a drop of oak, so its fruit really sings. Expect punchy aromas of melon and pineapple and subtle hints of vanilla and sweet spices. Sublime with roast chicken.

column1: Acacia Road Chenin Blanc 2022/23, South Africa
column2: Chenin Blanc has found a home in South Africa and this example shows exactly why with bright flavours of tropical fruit and apple followed by a honeyed yet refreshing finish.
It's the weeknight sipper to bring a splash of sun to your sofa. Gentle oak influence gifts a silkiness to a bouquet of dark plum and blackcurrants. This really is a steal at a pocket-friendly price.

South Africa is a fabulous place to look for innovative and great value wines.  This Sauvignon is lively and fresh with an abundance of zingy grapefuit and apple flavours softened by hints of ripe melon. Grapefruit and green apple shine from the glass with a lovely honeydew melon to soften the finish. A marvellous addition to a lovely fish dish or mixed vegetable platter.

column1: Reyneke 'Vinehugger' Organic Chenin Blanc 2021/22, South Africa
column2: Johan Reyneke is one of South Africa's most celebrated producers. With winemaker Rudiger Gretschel on board, the Reyneke winery was described as one of the country's 'First Growths' by Tim Atkin MW. This Chenin Blanc has notes of quince and pineapple, well integrated acidity and a long finish.

You’ll be in good company when you uncork a bottle of this Brut. It’s affectionately known as the ‘President’s Choice’ because it was served at both Nelson Mandela’s inauguration and Barack Obama’s presidential win. It’s made with the Méthode Cap Classique – a style identical to the traditional method used to make Champagne, using Chardonnay and Pinot Noir too. It means it’s a real steal for fizz fans who love the taste of Champagne – but not the price. Fresh but creamy. Full of limey citrus flavours – it’s got a lovely brioche richness from its second fermentation in the bottle. Fantastic with cheesy nibbles.

column1: The Whale Cove Sauvignon Blanc 2021/22, South Africa
column2: Origin Wine was established in Stellenbosch in 2002, and has made leaps and bounds since. Today, they're proud to present an entirely vegan-friendly range. To craft this deeply refreshing Sauvignon Blanc, grapes are carefully selected from several sites across the Western Cape. This cool-climate area is renowned for producing vibrant and fruity Sauvignon, so if you're a Marlborough fan, Whale Cove is a fantastic alternative choice. It’s balanced and refreshing with crisp flavours of citrus, apple and herbs. Partner with pan-fried salmon.

column2: Dive into this Pinotage rosé. Its approachable hints of red fruit and floral notes make a perfect partner with light salads and canapes.

column1: Rupert & Rothschild 'Baroness Nadine' Chardonnay 2021/22, South Africa
column2: The Rothschild family’s winemaking legacy began in 1868, when James de Rothschild bought the prestigious Château Lafite in Bordeaux. Over a century later, his great-grandson Baron Edmond decided to take his passion and expertise to South Africa. There, in partnership with businessman and philanthropist Dr Anton Rupert, he began producing French-style wines in picturesque Franschhoek. The estate is now managed by the next generation of both families – and the wines continue to attract international acclaim. This Chardonnay was named in honour of Baron Edmond’s wife, Baroness Nadine de Rothschild. And with its elegance and sophistication, it’s a fitting tribute. Discover notes of grapefruit and lemon peel, plus hints of vanilla, cinnamon and toasted hazelnut. Its citrusy character and long, mineral finish make it an ideal match for fish and seafood dishes.

Paul Cluver is a family-owned winery based in Elgin, South Africa. After noticing the region's potential for cool-climate winemaking, they ripped our the apple trees and planted vines in the mid 19th century. Today, they're fondly recognised by wine critics for their great value. This is a fresh and expressive Sauvignon Blanc, with notes of grapefruit and gooseberries. Try it with pesto pasta.

Reyneke believe there’s a lot to be said about the way wine used to be made. Back when the farm started over 150 years ago, there were no chemicals involved in keeping vines healthy. So that’s why, in 2000, they switched to fully organic, biodynamic practices. Their wines have since won countless awards, and in 2020 they were described as one of South Africa’s ‘First Growth’ wineries by top critic Tim Atkin MW. This juicy red is a brilliant demonstration of their skill. Part of the wine spends eight months in oak, making it smooth and approachable. You’ll find notes of plum, blackcurrant and peppery spice that are perfect with lamb dishes.
column9: Red Fruit, Black Fruit, Black Pepper

column1: Trizanne Signature Wines 'TSW' Marsanne-Roussanne 2020, South Africa
column2: Trizanne Barnard cut her teeth at the world-famous Klein Constantia winery. But now she's making her own path in the wine world with Trizanne Signature Wines. She grows all of her grapes on the sun-drenched slopes of Noordhoek in the southern Peninsula. You can taste just how well they ripen in these conditions in this blend of Marsanne and Roussanne. It's intense and silky, with notes of citrus, stone fruit, and a delicious mineral edge. Pair this with a delicious fatty fish, like poached salmon.
Trizanne Barnard earned her stripes at the iconic Klein Constantia winery. In 2008, she went her own way. This Cinsault is punchy and floral, with flayers of fruit and spice and a crisp acidity.

column1: MAN Family Wines 'Outentiek' Syrah 2020, South Africa
column2: MAN Family Wines was founded by three friends who often stayed up too late talking about how to make a living from winemaking. Their approach is to keep things honest and straightforward. That's why this wine is named Outentiek, which is Afrikaans for 'authentic'. They deliberately avoided too much oak and the fruit-forward style of Shiraz you may expect from South Africa. It's a medium-bodied, peppery Syrah with bright red-fruit notes and polished tannins. Try it with crispy pork belly.

column1: Klein Constantia Vin de Constance 2019, Constantia
column2: Described as one of the world’s most picturesque wine estates, Klein Constantia is renowned for much more than its beauty. Aside from a fine collection of still wines, there's one bottling in particular that put this 17th-century estate on the world stage. Vin de Constance was admired by legendary writers, leaders and aristocracy throughout 18th-century Europe, and its stellar reputation remains to this day. The cool foothills of Constantiaberg are the perfect location for growing its Muscat de Frontignan grapes. Ahead of bottling, it’s aged for three years in oak, acacia and foudres barrels, adding to its complex character. In your glass, you’ll find this luscious wine expresses the region’s cool climate; expect elegance, balance and freshness. Discover intense and aromatic notes of honeysuckle, creamy lemon tart, exotic fruits, ginger and a hint of saffron. If you only try one dessert wine this year, the one-of-kind iconic Vin de Constance should be top of your list. Critics James Suckling and Tim Atkin both awarded this vintage 96+ points in their South Africa Report 2022. Hold it for up to a decade - if you can resist opening it.

South Africa’s Robertson has the terroir and climate to allow a range of grape varieties to flourish. Nestled between the sun-drenched Langeberg Mountains and the fertile reaches of the Breede River, Chardonnay vines here thrive in vineyards tempered by ocean breezes. Named after the region itself, the Robertson winery is housed within an ancient stone missionary church – a nod towards the region’s 150 years of heritage. And community is at the heart of everything they do. As a major employer in the valley, the team is committed to giving back. They recently set up the ‘Really Good Wine’ initiative, a project set up to invest in local education. Thirty-five different farms now make up the Robertson Winery community, some of whom have been growing grapes in the valley for seven generations. Winemaker Rianco van Rooyen’s experiences in both California and Bordeaux have contributed to his aromatically intense and fruit-forward style of wine, as this first-rate Chardonnay effortlessly shows. Expect ripe flavours of lemon, melon and a subtle creamy nuttiness. Its refreshing acidity and rounded body makes it a great choice for rich poultry dishes.

When brother and sister winemaking team Abrie and Jeanette Bruwer visited Argentina, they fell in love with Albariño. So they made the second to ever be made in South Africa's Cape. It's crafted sustainably with a 'hands off' approach and only in small quantities. But what little there is tastes fantastic. It's complex and rich, with flavours of apricot, nectarine and that vital saline minerality. Try this with white fish or oysters.

column2: This is an unoaked Chardonnay, made in the time-honoured method of wild yeast fermentation. This allows the natural yeasts present on the grapes to bring about fermentation, which takes a lengthy 60 days, but promotes greater richness and complexity of flavour. Immensely complex aromas of pineapple and pear mingling with nutty, yeasty cookie dough notes from extended lees ageing. The palate structure is firm, crisp and grippy. Drink with roasted or barbecued sea bass, trout or tuna.

Rustenberg’s Murray Barlow is the only person to be named Young Winemaker of the Year twice by Diners Club. And he’s a specialist in creating exceptional reds under the Stellenbosch sun. This is a blend of Shiraz, Merlot and Cabernet Sauvignon. An unconventional mixture of traditional Bordeaux and Rhône varieties that creates something truly fantastic. It has flavours of blackcurrant, black pepper and spice that are a treat with a chargrilled steak.

Villiera Wines has been in the Grier family’s hands since 1983. And as well as making delicious wines, they’re renowned for their strong ethical and sustainable missions. The winery is solar-powered, uses no insecticides and plants thousands of indigenous trees to promote biodiversity. What’s more, they’re also a wildlife sanctuary and home to the Pebbles Project and the Owethu Clinic. It’s safe to say they love their environment – and this all translates to healthy vines and maximum flavour. This traditional method sparkling wine is a blend of handpicked Chardonnay and Pinot noir and spends around 18 months ageing on its lees for extra texture and flavour. It’s fresh and zesty, with complex notes of brioche. The refreshing acidity makes it a brilliant pairing for sushi or grilled asparagus.

Vergelegen Estate is the third-oldest wine producing estate in South Africa. Established in 1700, this heritage estate is known for crafting wines of exceptional quality. Grapes are meticulously picked by hand and crafted in their innovative gravity-flow winery. They're all about purity of fruit, and you’ll certainly taste it in this elegant bottle. Expect vibrant flavours of guava, passionfruit lime blossom and quince.

This is made predominantly from Merlot and is matured for over a year in French oak. Discover juicy flavours of raspberry, cherry and plum, with notes of forest floor and toasty oak spice. A hint of smokiness makes it a wonderful choice for roast duck.

Grapes here benefit from a luxuriously long ripening period, allowing complex flavours to develop slowly. They get to soak up the sun and be cooled by sea breezes. Most importantly, it brings plenty of flavour to your glass. Oak ageing brings heady flavours of cream, honey, butterscotch and brioche. Decadently rich, it's fantastic with buttery roast chicken.

Decide for yourself in this exceptional Chenin Blanc. It has rich notes of green apple, stone fruits and honey and a lingering aftertaste.

Kanonkop was named Outstanding Producer of the Past 50 Years at the International Wine and Spirits Competition in 2019. The family-owned estate is considered to many as the equivalent of a South African First Growth. And when you taste what they've done with the country's star grape, Pinotage, you'll know why. Made in a soft, fruit-forward style, it spends 12 months in French oak barrels to give a silky-smooth texture. This is a complex Pinotage wine, with notes of raspberry, strawberry, red cherry and chocolate. Try it with a hearty beef burger.
column9: Coffee, Black Cherry, Black Plum, Blackberry, Blackcurrant

column2: Wine has been made at Kanonkop since the 1940s, but it wasn’t until 1973 that the iconic label was created. Today, the winery has an international reputation as one of the finest in Stellenbosch. Their production is focused around South African signature grape, Pinotage, and Cabernet Sauvignon. Wines are made from vines in the Perdeberg – the largest single block of Pinotage in the world. Very few estates attempt to make rosé from this robust, full-flavoured grape, but Kanonkop have perfected the art. It's wonderfully perfumed, with notes of Turkish delight, rose water, summer berries and crisp red apple. Rich and fruity but with plenty of freshness, this will pair brilliantly with sushi.

Here’s a wine that celebrates the South African sunshine: DeMorgenzon means ‘the morning sun’ in Afrikaans. The name comes from the vineyard’s location. At a high altitude of 250-300 metres above sea level, it’s the first spot in the Stellenbosch Kloof Valley to catch the day's rays. This is made from 100% Chenin Blanc vines planted in the 1970s. It's wonderfully balanced with both freshness and complexity, thanks to barrel fermentation. It’s a lushly fragrant wine – think orange blossom, pear, caramel and spice. There’s plenty of mouth-watering acidity, too, which means it will cut through creamy sauces with aplomb. Try it with a carbonara.

The Rubicon is a South African classic. It's made by the Meerlust estate, which has been in the Myburgh family since 1756. And it paved the way for the country's Bordeaux blends that are rightfully celebrated today. This has notes of black fruit, cedar, tobacco leaf and spice. Decant for an hour and serve at room temperature with roast lamb.

Patient drinkers will be able to age this for 10-15 years, but open now to enjoy concentrated flavours of cassis, black cherries and herbs. Try with a grilled steak. The grapes for this Sauvignon are plucked from mountainous south-west facing vines, so they get maximum sun exposure. The 2022 vintage was awarded 93 Points by James Suckling – what’s more, it was his highest ranked South African wine in his ‘Top 100 Best Value Wines of 2022’ list at number 30. It has refreshing notes of elderflower, citrus, white peach and tropical fruit. Delicious with tempura prawns.

It's spent time on its lees. This process transforms the wine into something more textured and complex. It’s full-bodied with a balancing fresh finish. Expect notes of citrus, pineapple and honey. column1: Gabb Family Vineyards Cabernet Sauvignon 2020/21, South Africa
column2: Although the Gabb family are originally from Shropshire, their premium Stellenbosch wines have made them renowned in South Africa. Their picturesque vineyards are situated 6 miles from False Bay. The maritime climate and granite-based soils are reminiscent of Bordeaux, so it’s no surprise that Cabernet Sauvignon thrives here. To make this wine, the selected grapes are chilled for two days prior to fermentation, allowing unique flavours to develop. 18 months barrel-aging in various types of oak adds further layers of delicious flavour. Expect intense, ripe aromas of blackberry, cassis and rich Christmas fruitcake. It’s full-bodied yet juicy and elegant. A hint of tobacco smoke and structured tannins make this a delicious pairing for beef short ribs.

Long recognised for producing premium wines, Meerlust Estate has a winemaking history dating back to 1756. They were pioneers of Bordeaux varietals in the Cape, producing Bordeaux-style blends with a unique South African flair. Meerlust means ‘pleasure of the sea’, as the vineyards are refreshed by ocean breezes and evening mists which roll in from the coast. This allows the grapes to ripen slowly, developing complex flavours but retaining freshness too. Produced from decades-old vines, this complex Merlot is aged for 18 months in oak before it’s released. Its intense flavour and structure means it can age for up to another decade or more – so it’s no surprise leading critic Tim Atkin awarded it 91 points. Expect opulent notes of ripe bramble fruits, dark chocolate and spice. Its silky tannins and rich flavours make it a great match for red meats.

column2: Think South Africa is all baking sunshine? Think again. Grown high in the Stellenbosch hills, the grapes for this wine are blessed by ocean breezes and a soaking morning sun. This prime location means robust and juicy flavour. Discover vibrant notes of violets, black berries and a hint of black pepper. Will complement any meat dishes, especially those prepared on coals.

Kanonkop is named after a kopje (hillock) in the nearby Simonsberg mountains. But there is more than pretty landscapes to mark this Stellenbosch winery out as special. In the 1970s, Paul Sauer noted the site’s suitability for grape-growing and planted vineyards on the granite soils to great success. Now, Kanonkop’s flagship bottling – a Bordeaux-style blend of Cabernet Sauvignon, Merlot and Cabernet Franc – is one of South Africa’s most prestigious wines. Expect complex notes of blackcurrant, wildflowers and cigar box. Enjoy it with prime rib.

column2: The Rustenberg winery dates back to 1682, when German Roelof Pasman recognised the farm’s grape-growing potential. It’s been operated by the Barlow family for the past 80 years, and they’ve created some exceptional bottles. Today, head winemaker is Murray Barlow, the only person to win Diners Club's Young Winemaker of the Year award twice. This is his finest Chardonnay, and it comes highly sought after. The grapes behind it are hand-harvested, and the wine aged for 16 months in oak to give a creamy finish. It’s complex and full-bodied, with plenty of ripe citrus, melon and peach flavours. Try it with rich chicken or pork dishes or age it for a decade. In 2022, this wine won an IWC award for the 2020 vintage.

In 2002, Jean-Claude and Carolyn Martin struck up the courage to start the Creation winery on the picturesque Hemel-en-Aarde ridge. Back then, this lofty spot had never seen a vine before. Today, they create exceptional Chardonnay sustainably and you'll get the high-altitude benefits in every sip. This is a Burgundy-style Chardonnay with South African sensibilities, expect flavours of peach, pear and vanilla and a refreshing minerality. Jean-Claude and Carolyn suggest pairing it with creamy pasta.

Hamilton Russell Vineyards boasts a lot of superlatives. They’re one of the most southerly vineyards in Africa. They were pioneers in now-celebrated Hemel-en-Aarde Valley, producing the first vintage back in 1981. And they’re one of South Africa’s finest wineries, often compared to the finest of Burgundy. Thanks to their southerly spot, they have a cool climate that's perfect for Chardonnay and Pinot Noir. They keep yields small on the vineyard, and intense demand keeps these elegant estate-grown wines in short supply. When you taste this Chardonnay, you'll see what the fuss is about. It has prominent pear and lime notes, bright natural acidity, a hint of oak and a refreshing minerality. It's textured, intense and certainly not lacking personality. Try it with a mushroom risotto or roasted chicken. Tim Atkin MW gave the 2020 vintage 96 points.

Boekenhoutskloof and winemaker Marc Kent are behind one of our classic fine wines, The Chocolate Block. And they've smashed the target again with this Cabernet Sauvignon. This is a smooth, textured wine, with notes of black fruit, graphite, sweet spice and cocoa. Decant for an hour and serve at room temperature with meatballs.

Boekenhoutskloof began in 1776 and is now in the very capable hands of Marc Kent, one of the biggest names in South African wine. Tim Atkin MW labelled them a First Growth in his 2021 South Africa report, and this is one of the most in-demand Syrahs in the country. It has concentrated notes of blackcurrant, black olive, ripe plums, cardamom and black pepper. Match with a dish that can stand up to plenty of flavour, like barbecued ribs or juicy beef burgers.

column2: Honey Drop wines, produced at the renowned Journey's End vineyards, are big, bold, and unmistakably characterful. And this wine is no exception. Made with some of the oldest bush-vine Chenin Blanc in Swartland, each bottle is the result of a mission to sustainably produce wines that are both delicious and environmentally conscious. Only grapes deemed perfectly ripe are picked by hand, and careful use of oak in the winery adds complex layers of woody notes and rich texture. Expect creamy tropical and peachy notes under rich layers of oak and vanilla. The refreshing acidity makes it a great partner for roast pork dishes.

column2: The Chocolate Block is a cult favourite – it usually sells out before it even hits the shop floor. It’s made by Boekenhoutskloof, named South Africa’s Winery of the Year 2020. Their winemaker, Marc Kent, is secretive about exactly how this wine is made. He tweaks the blend with every vintage, so no two Chocolate Blocks are quite the same. But it’s always a blend of rich and ripe varieties: Syrah, Grenache, Cinsault, Cabernet Sauvignon – with a touch of Viognier for added perfume. It’s seriously plush and full of plum, blackberry, blueberry and cherry flavours. Smooth, supple, with fine tannins – it’s made to go with food. Fantastic with aromatic lamb tagine.

He creates this from the same vineyards with a wide variety of traditional Rhône grape varieties. It's rich and full-bodied, with flavours of red fruits, sweet spices and pepper. Try it with a vegetable chilli.

column2: This is from an estate with a mission to showcase the magic of Swartland's old vines. The vines behind the wines are at least 35 years old. Older vines nourish tastier grapes, so you can be certain that this Chenin Blanc is packed with complex and rich flavour. Expect luscious notes of apricot, nectarine and flowers, and a balancing acidity. Perfect with seared scallops.

column1: Boekenhoutskloof 'The Chocolate Block' 2020/21 Magnum, Western Cape
column2: An exciting blend of 5 grape varieties, from innovative winemaker Marc Kent. Dominated by around 67% Syrah, the grapes come from several specially selected blocks of vines on Boukenhoutskoloof's estate, fermented and aged for up to 18 months in old French oak. An earthy, rustic nose gives up aromas of leather, earth and spices over a backdrop of blackcurrant and ripe raspberry fruit. Harmonious and powerful on the palate, with a cocoa and pepper complexity. Most at home with spice-rubbed steaks, roast rib of beef, or game dishes.
